Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Enabling Quantum Leap: Room-temperature Photon Blockade and Quantum Gates Using Quantum Dots in 2D Materials
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: Remarkable progress in the development of quantum computers has been made in recent years, but leading-edge quantum hardware still suffers from major limitations, including operation only under extreme environments (such as ultracold temperatures) and difficulties in scaling to larger systems. This project focuses on a platform that may alleviate these drawbacks and enable operation of building blocks for quantum computers in friendly environments such as at room temperature, as well as facilitate system scaling. The platform consists of two-dimensional ultrathin materials with quantum dots capable of controllably emitting single photons of light. Such materials are coupled to optical resonators that are able to recirculate photons, ultimately allowing control of the flow of light, and therefore the information in the system. The project includes educational and outreach activities integrated with research, which the PIs have already initiated, including active recruitment of minorities and women for science and engineering careers, development of new classes and textbooks, undergraduate research and advising, and participation in outreach programs for K-12 students and teachers.

Technical description: Photon blockade - in which the presence of a single photon in a system (resonator) blocks another photon from entering it - is the ultimate demonstration of a nonlinearity at a single photon level. It is the underlying phenomenon behind many proposals for implementation of nontrivial two photon qubit quantum gates and quantum simulators. This project focuses on the demonstration of photon blockade using a new platform: a single quantum dot created in a two-dimensional material coupled to an optical nanocavity. The platform of 2D materials, which has already been shown to allow single quantum emitter behavior in a variety of systems, provides important advantages in terms of ease of placement of the quantum dot and its spectral tunability. The planned experiments constitute a new approach for quantum science and engineering using two-dimensional materials and have the potential to advance quantum engineering and cavity quantum electrodynamics by enabling room-temperature, scalable experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Light, when steered into the realm of quantum mechanics, become particle-like photons that act differently when one, two, or more are present. Single photons are generated from quantum emitters (QEs), which thus are the key building block for advances in quantum information science and technology. The ideal platform would be a scalable solid-state chip, where the QEs can be arbitrarily created on a photonic substrate, precisely placed in position, and dynamically tuned in spectral energy. 2D materials appear to be the most promising route to meet all these requirements, thanks to the materials? substrate-indiscriminative, van der Waals bonding nature, and thus enabled high engineerability. 

In this project, a team of Stanford university researchers investigated QEs in 2D materials of both semiconducting and insulating types. We address fundamental issues that currently limit the QEs, including their large spatial and spectral variability, unknown localization origins, and spin-forbidden nature of host materials.

For QEs in 2D semiconductors, we have applied a new strain-confinement technique to demonstrate quantum emission in a monolayer of the transition metal dichalcogenide MoSe2. Using this new material system and fabrication approach we have achieved: (i) The first quantum emission through a spin-allowed transition from a 2D semiconductor. (ii) Radiative rates of QEs exceed by 100x those of existing 2D semiconductor platforms. This implies a corresponding increase in data communication rates and the ability to reach the strong coupling regime. (iii) Arbitrary spatial positioning of localized emitters using a new strain-control method.  A representative example of a collection of such quantum emitters is shown in the figure, which displays both a topographical image obtained with atomic force microscopy and the corresponding optical emission map.

For QEs in a representative 2D insulator, hexagonal boron nitride (hBN), we directly correlate quantum emission with local strain using a combination of photoluminescence (PL), cathodoluminescence (CL) and nanobeam electron diffraction. CL mapping reveals that multiple QEs of distinct species located within an optically diffraction-limited region can each contribute to the observed PL spectra. Local strain maps indicate that strain is not required to activate the emitters and is not solely responsible for our observed emission range. Instead, at least four distinct QE classes are responsible, and all four classes are stable upon both optical and electron illumination. 

Our investigation provides a foundation to further advance QEs in 2D materials, through optical characterization at atomic scales, and through optical control of charge, spin, and valley degrees of freedom at a single quantum level.

During the project, multiple graduate students and postdoctoral researchers (across the combined team) received broad interdisciplinary training and experience in collaborative research through this program. Within this group of these junior research participants, about 50% were female. These research participants developed expertise in state-of-the-art nanoscale technology, optical measurements, 2D material preparation, and device fabrication, as well as in the preparation of scientific results for publication and presentation at professional meetings.
